oopsy, that was my mistake
all those instructions are telling you to do is remove flash, enable the partner repo, and then install the "adobe-flashplugin" package, which is the Adobe Flash entry in the Software Center.
how is that different from just removing flash then installing adobe flash directly?
err, probably not any different, but what do you mean by "directly"?
I mean going to the adobe flash site and using their download to install

do they provide a .deb file? Otherwise, it's no different at the moment, but differs in that the system will keep track of the package and install newer versions if/when they become available in the repositories.
plus, then it's far easier to install and uninstall. Always less messy to have the package manager keep track of things.
the download adds a link to software center to install, I don't know if it adds a .deb file or not
I just checked, yeah, all it does in theory is add the partner repo to the repository lists, so it's no different than adding the lines to /etc/apt/sources.list yourself.
does that mean it updates?
Yeah, as long as Adobe deigns to push the newer versions into the repository.
so what I did in the instructions I was given was no different then using the file from adobe to install in the software center?
as far as I can tell, yeah, no difference at all.
do I need to shut down all flash before installing flash?
naw, whatever flash is running may keep running, but the fact that it's open won't matter one way or another for replacing the actual install.
